edge: Toy Story 3 is a 2010 American animated comedy-drama film
Toy Story 3 is produced by Pixar Animation Studios for Walt Disney Pictures
Lee Unkrich, the editor of the first two films and the co-director of Toy Story 2, directed Toy Story 3
Darla K. Anderson produced Toy Story 3
Michael Arndt wrote the screenplay for Toy Story 3
John Lasseter and Andrew Stanton, respectively, director and co-writer of the first two films, wrote the story for Toy Story 3 with Lee Unkrich
Toy Story 3 is the third installment in the Toy Story series
In Toy Story 3, Andy Davis, now a teenager, is going to college
Woody, one of the main toys in the series, appears in Toy Story 3
Buzz Lightyear, another main toy in the series, appears in Toy Story 3
In Toy Story 3, the toys are accidentally donated to Sunnyside Daycare, a daycare center
Andy's mother accidentally donates the toys to Sunnyside Daycare in Toy Story 3

The voice cast of Toy Story 3 includes several prominent actors such as Tom Hanks, Tim Allen, Joan Cusack, Don Rickles, Wallace Shawn, John Ratzenberger, Estelle Harris, Jeff Pidgeon, Jodi Benson, John Morris, Laurie Metcalf, and R. Lee Ermey

In 2004, following disagreements between the Walt Disney Company's CEO Michael Eisner and Pixar CEO Steve Jobs, Disney planned to make Toy Story 3 at the new Circle Seven Animation studio unit with the tentative theatrical release date in early 2008. However, after Disney bought Pixar in early 2006, the Circle Seven version of the film was canceled as the result of Circle Seven's closure.
With a budget of $200 million, Toy Story 3 is one of the most expensive films of all time.
Premiered at the Taormina Film Fest in Italy on June 12, 2010.
Released in the United States on June 18.
Was the first film to be released theatrically with Dolby Surround 7.1 sound.
Received critical acclaim upon release, with critics praising the vocal performances, screenplay, emotional depth, animation, and Newman's musical score.
Finished its theatrical run as the highest-grossing film of 2010.

node_2: highest-grossing animated film of all time
edge: Was the first animated film to reach $1 billion at the box-office, and was Pixar's highest-grossing film until the release of Incredibles 2 in 2018.
Named Toy Story 3 one of the top-ten films of 2010.
Named Toy Story 3 one of the top-ten films of 2010.
Was nominated for five awards at the 83rd Academy Awards, winning Best Animated Feature and Best Original Song.

Was nominated for Best Picture, thus making it the third and currently most recent animated film to be nominated for this award (after 1991's Beauty and the Beast and 2009's Up), although it lost to The King's Speech.
A sequel, Toy Story 4, was released in 2019.
Andy Davis is leaving for college and intends to take Woody with him.

edge: Buzz Lightyear, Jessie, and the others believe Andy intended to throw them away and join Barbie in a donation box bound for Sunnyside Daycare.

edge: Barbie is in the donation box bound for Sunnyside Daycare.

Bonnie finds Woody and takes him to her house, playing with him and her other toys.
The toddlers play roughly with Andy's toys at Sunnyside.
Buzz asks Lotso to have himself and his friends moved to the older children’s room, but is instead captured.
Lotso has Buzz switched to demo mode and brainwashes him into believing Lotso is his commander.
Mrs. Potato Head loses an eye in Andy's room.
Andy searches for his toys, including Woody.
Woody and Lotso initially work together to avoid a shredder but Lotso abandons them after that.
Most of the toys are placed on a conveyor belt leading to an incinerator at the local landfill.
Woody and his friends help Lotso reach the emergency stop button for the incinerator but Lotso abandons them.
Woody and his friends ride a garbage truck, driven by Sid Phillips, back to Andy's house.
Woody ends up at the bottom of the donation box and is initially passed over by Andy but is eventually recognized by Bonnie.
The toys learn that Barbie, Ken, and Big Baby have improved the lives of the toys at Sunnyside for Bonnie.

The Sunnyside Daycare toys are voiced by Lee Unkrich as the jack-in-the-box, Teddy Newton as Chatter Telephone, Woody Smith as Big Baby, Whoopi Goldberg as Stretch, Jack Angel as Chunk, Jan Rabson as Spark and Richard Kind as the Bookworm; This indicates a connection between Stretch and Bookworm.

The Sunnyside Daycare toys are voiced by Lee Unkrich as the jack-in-the-box, Teddy Newton as Chatter Telephone, Woody Smith as Big Baby, Whoopi Goldberg as Stretch, Jack Angel as Chunk, Jan Rabson as Spark and Richard Kind as the Bookworm; This signifies a relation between Sid and Toy Story 3.

The Sunnyside Daycare toys are voiced by Lee Unkrich as the jack-in-the-box, Teddy Newton as Chatter Telephone, Woody Smith as Big Baby, Whoopi Goldberg as Stretch, Jack Angel as Chunk, Jan Rabson as Spark and Richard Kind as the Bookworm; This indicates a connection between Sunnyside and Toy Story 3.
According to the terms of Pixar Animation Studios' initial seven-film deal with the Walt Disney Company, all characters created by Pixar for their films were owned and controlled by Disney.
Disney owned the rights to make sequels to all Pixar films up to and including Cars, according to the terms of Pixar Animation Studios' initial seven-film deal with the Walt Disney Company.

When the contentious negotiations between the two companies made a split appear likely, Michael Eisner, Disney chairman at the time, put plans in motion to produce Toy Story 3 at a new Disney studio, Circle Seven Animation.
Tim Allen, the voice of Buzz Lightyear, indicated a willingness to return, even if Pixar was not on board.
Toy Story 3 was slated for a theatrical release sometime in spring 2008 at Circle Seven Animation, when the contentious negotiations between Pixar and Disney made a split appear likely.

node_2: disney's direct-to-video sequels such as the hunchback of notre dame ii and the lion king 1½
edge: Bradley Raymond was hired to direct the film, which is a part of Disney's series of direct-to-video sequels that includes The Hunchback of Notre Dame II and The Lion King 1½.

node_1: teacher's pet screenwriters bill and cheri steinkellner
edge: Among the scripts Circle Seven had under consideration was one from Teacher's Pet screenwriters Bill and Cheri Steinkellner, which involves a whodunit-style murder mystery story.

node_2: his grandmother's house for the night
edge: In their idea for the film, Andy's toys (Woody, Buzz, Hamm, Rex, Slinky, Mr. Potato Head, Jessie, and Bullseye) pay a visit to his grandmother's house for the night because his room is getting remodeled.

node_2: a set of andy's toys and new characters hee-hee and gladiola
edge: In their idea for the film, a set of Andy's toys (Woody, Buzz, Hamm, Rex, Slinky, Mr. Potato Head, Jessie, and Bullseye) and new characters Hee-Hee and Gladiola try to figure out who’s stealing the toys one by one.

node_2: meet the parents screenwriter jim herzfeld
edge: The final version of the Circle Seven script was written by Meet the Parents screenwriter Jim Herzfeld.

While searching on the Internet, they then discovered that many more Buzz Lightyear toys are malfunctioning around the world and the company had issued a massive recall. Fearing Buzz's destruction, a group of Andy's toys (Woody, Rex, Slinky, Mr. Potato Head, Hamm, Jessie, and Bullseye) all ship themselves to Taiwan and venture out to rescue Buzz.

Fearing Buzz's destruction, a group of Andy's toys (Woody, Rex, Slinky, Mr. Potato Head, Hamm, Jessie, and Bullseye) all ship themselves to Taiwan and venture out to rescue Buzz. At the same time, they then discovered that many more Buzz Lightyear toys are malfunctioning around the world and the company had issued a massive recall.

node_2: woody, rex, slinky, mr. potato head, hamm, jessie, bullseye
edge: A group of Andy's toys (Woody, Rex, Slinky, Mr. Potato Head, Hamm, Jessie, and Bullseye) all ship themselves to Taiwan and venture out to rescue Buzz. Along with meeting the recalled toys, Buzz meets Rosey, a warm cozy toy, and Jade, a leggy doll with an evening gown.
Along with meeting the recalled toys, Buzz also meets a new Star Command action figure that was going to be the replacement of Buzz, Daxx Blastar,
Along with meeting the recalled toys and a new Star Command action figure that was going to be the replacement of Buzz, Daxx Blastar, also meets his accessory pet cat named Comet.

In January 2006, Disney bought Pixar in a deal that put Pixar chiefs Edwin Catmull and John Lasseter in charge of all Disney Animation. Shortly thereafter, Circle Seven Animation was shut down and its alternate version of Toy Story 3 was canceled.
The following month, Disney CEO Robert Iger confirmed that Disney was in the process of transferring the production to Pixar.
Shortly thereafter, Circle Seven Animation was shut down and its alternate version of Toy Story 3 was canceled.
The studio's brain trust, which included John Lasseter, Andrew Stanton, Pete Docter, and Lee Unkrich, had their own idea for a sequel that they had carried around for years.
In January 2006, Disney bought Pixar in a deal that put Pixar chiefs Edwin Catmull and John Lasseter in charge of all Disney Animation. Circle Seven Animation was shut down.
Woody belonged to Andy, who left for college, causing Woody and his toy-box friends to be dumped in a daycare center.
Woody and his toy-box friends were dumped in a daycare center after Andy left for college.

node_1: circle seven version of the film
edge: The filmmakers did not read the script for the Circle Seven version of the film out of spite, but they wanted to start fresh and not be influenced by what they'd done.

node_1: circle seven version of the film
edge: The filmmakers did not look at any of the work done for the Circle Seven version of the film to start fresh.

node_1: initial development stages of the film
edge: Pixar revisited their work from the original Toy Story and found error messages preventing them from editing the files, necessitating recreation from scratch during the initial development stages of the film.

Hayao Miyazaki's niece inspired the character Mei in My Neighbour Totoro (1988). Dolby Laboratories announced that Toy Story 3 would be the first film to feature theatrical 7.1 surround sound. Daisuke Tsutsumi, the art director of Toy Story 3, is married to Hayao Miyazaki's niece.
Toy Story 3 had its worldwide premiere on June 12, 2010, opening at Taormina Film Fest in Italy.
In the United States, it premiered on June 13, 2010,
El Capitan Theatre in Hollywood, California hosted the Toy Story 3 premiere on June 13, 2010.
The film was released to IMAX 3D theaters along with its wide release on June 18, 2010.
The film was theatrically accompanied by the Pixar short film Day & Night.
On October 2, 2009, Toy Story and Toy Story 2 were re-released as a double feature in Disney Digital 3-D.
The first teaser trailer was released with Up in Disney Digital 3-D on May 29, 2009.
A second full-length trailer appeared in 3D showings of Alice in Wonderland and How to Train Your Dragon.
Mattel produced toys to promote the film.
Thinkway Toys produced toys to promote the film.
Lego produced toys to promote the film.
Fisher Price, a Mattel Company, released Toy Story 3 with 21 3D images for viewing with the View-Master viewer.
Disney Interactive Studios produced a video game based on the film Toy Story 3: The Video Game.
Toy Story 3: The Video Game was released for Microsoft Windows.
Toy Story 3: The Video Game was released for Xbox 360.
Toy Story 3: The Video Game was released for Wii.
Toy Story 3: The Video Game was released for PlayStation 3.
Toy Story 3: The Video Game was released for Nintendo DS.
Toy Story 3: The Video Game was released for PSP.
A PlayStation 2 version of the game was released as part of a PS2 bundle and separately on November 2, 2010.
Toy Story 3 was featured in Apple's iPhone OS 4 Event on April 8, 2010.
A Japanese version of the commercial for the toy Lots-O'-Huggin' Bear was released online, with the name "Little Hug-Hug Bear" replacing "Lots-O'-Huggin Bear".

node_2: highest-grossing animated film of all time
edge: Toy Story 3 earned $415 million in the United States and Canada and $652 million in other countries for a worldwide total of $1.067 billion, becoming the highest-grossing animated film of all time until it was surpassed by Frozen (2013) in 2014.
On its first weekend, Toy Story 3 topped the worldwide box office with $145.3 million ($153.7 million with weekday previews), becoming the highest-grossing film of 2010.

node_2: over 52 million tickets sold in the u.s.
edge: Box Office Mojo estimates that the film sold over 52 million tickets in the U.S.

node_2: opening day record for an animated film
edge: Toy Story 3 earned $41.1 million on its opening day (June 18, 2010) from 4,028 theaters, including $4 million at midnight shows from about 1,500 theaters, setting an opening-day record for an animated film until surpassed by Minions and later Finding Dory.
On August 27, 2010 – its seventy-first day of release, it surpassed the $1 billion mark.
During its opening weekend, the film topped the box office with $110.3 million, setting an opening-weekend record among Pixar films.
set an opening-weekend record among Pixar films
achieved the second-largest opening weekend among animated films
achieved the fourth-largest opening weekend among 2010 films
The film achieved an average of $27,385 per venue during its opening weekend.
The film's opening-week gross (Friday through Thursday) was $167.6 million.
Inside North America, Toy Story 3 did not top the box office three times. Outside of North America, it did.
Toy Story 3's highest-grossing market after North America is Japan, where it earned $126.7 million.
The United Kingdom was Toy Story 3's top international market, earning $115.4 million.
In Argentina, Toy Story 3 set a new opening-weekend record for animated films.
In China, Toy Story 3 set a new opening-weekend record for animated films.
On review aggregation website Rotten Tomatoes, Toy Story 3 has an approval rating of 98% based on 313 reviews.
On review aggregation website Rotten Tomatoes, Toy Story 3 has an approval rating of 98% based on 313 reviews.
with an average rating of 8.9/10.
On review aggregation website Rotten Tomatoes,
the site's critical consensus reads,
Deftly blending comedy, adventure, and honest emotion,
TIME named Toy Story 3 the "best film of 2010"
as did Quentin Tarantino until 2020 where the latter ranked fellow 2010 film The Social Network as the best film of the 2010s.
Metacritic, another review aggregator which assigns a normalized rating to reviews,
gave the film a score of 92 out of 100 based on 39 critics,
ranked the film at #11 on their list of "The 25 All-TIME Best Animated Films"
Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale,
but down from the "A+" earned by the first film.

node_2: a long, melancholy meditation on loss, impermanence and that noble, stubborn, foolish thing called love
edge: A. O. Scott of The New York Times stated that this film about the adventures of a bunch of silly plastic junk also explores themes of loss, impermanence, and love.
Michael Rechtshaffen of The Hollywood Reporter described Woody, Buzz, and their playmates' comeback in the film as 'thoroughly engaging'.

node_2: a digitally animated comedy about plastic playthings
edge: Owen Gleiberman from Entertainment Weekly labeled Toy Story 3 as 'a digitally animated comedy about plastic playthings'.

node_2: flabbergasted that a digitally animated comedy about plastic playthings could have this effect
edge: Owen Gleiberman from Entertainment Weekly expressed his surprise at being moved to tears by a computer-animated film about toys.

node_2: the best movie trilogy of all time
edge: Mark Kermode of the BBC gave the film, and the series, a glowing review, calling it 'the best movie trilogy of all time.'

node_2: the most emotional conclusion to the film series that made pixar famous.
edge: Roger Moore of the Orlando Sentinel, who gave the film 31⁄2 out of 4 stars, wrote 'Dazzling, scary, and sentimental, Toy Story 3 is a dark and emotional conclusion to the film series that made Pixar famous.'

node_2: an exceptionally slick and confident product, as opposed to a magical blend of commerce and popular art.
edge: Michael Phillips of the Chicago Tribune gave the film 3 out of 4 stars, writing that 'Compared with the riches of all kinds in recent Pixar masterworks such as Ratatouille, WALL-E, and Up, Toy Story 3 looks and plays like an exceptionally slick and confident product.'
In USA Today, Claudia Puig gave the film a complete 4-star rating, writing 'This installment, the best of the three, is everything a movie should be: hilarious, touching, exciting, and clever.'

Randy Newman composed and conducted the film score for Toy Story 3.
Randy Newman has composed and conducted film scores for six Pixar films, including Toy Story 3.
Initially, Disney released the soundtrack of Toy Story 3 only as a digital download.
This was the second instance where Disney did not release the award-winning soundtrack of a Pixar film on CD, the first being Up.
The film uses the track 'Dream Weaver' by Gary Wright.
The film also uses the track 'Le Freak' by Chic.
The tracks 'Cowboy!' and 'Come to Papa' included material from Randy Newman's rejected score for Air Force One.
Toy Story 3 was followed by Toy Story 4.
A fifth film titled Toy Story 5 is in development for release on June 19, 2026.
